body: @paulk-asert: Filter for `org.codehaus.groovy.transform.ASTTransformation` added
LGTM
Merged, thanks!
Awesome, thanks! :)
Ignore this proposal, we can just use classpath already.
@paulk-asert: No response for a while. Would be nice to get this into 2.5.3.

I haven't had time to refresh my memory on the requirements for the classloader parameter. I believe it's necessary for numerous scenarios, e.g. when using @Grab. Without that change, aren't the other changes worthless?

I don't now how @grab is working but the same thing this code does (get tccl for service loading)  already does the JDK itself. IMHO there is no reason to do this "twice". Yes, spifly only instrument usage of ServiceLoader.load without explict classloader because it does the tccl classloader weaving itself. (classic OSGi try/catch/finally block to temporary set tccl to a specific bundleclassloader)

+1 but agree some extra doco would be nice.
I'd suggest a yaml equivalent of "json-userguide.adoc".
I'd just move YamlParserTest and YamlBuilderTest into src/spec and just reference those.

@jwagenleitner I've fixed the issues you found. Thanks!
@paulk-asert  I've refined the docs and moved dependencies to `groovy-yaml` subproject
The implementation of YamlBuilder looks extremely inefficient. It converts the JSON to a string re-parses and converts it a back again. I'm not sure YamlBuilder should be included in this form.
This is a reference implementation, we can improve it when we have enough time. In addition, the `YamlBuilder` will be seldom used in projects, so it should be OK to include it IMO.
LGTM. Thanks for your contribution.
@paulk-asert : Did you already had time to refresh your memory. I still think it should be no problem to remove the classloader line to get current one.

Just in case, this is already verified

Doing the following on 2.5.2 breaks:

```
@Grab(group='org.ajoberstar', module='grgit', version='1.9.3')
import org.ajoberstar.grgit.Branch

Branch branch = new Branch(trackingBranch: new Branch())
```

with 

```
> Unsupported type (org.ajoberstar.grgit.Branch) found for field 'trackingBranch' while constructing immutable class org.ajoberstar.grgit.Branch.
Immutable classes only support properties with effectively immutable types including:
- Strings, primitive types, wrapper types, Class, BigInteger and BigDecimal, enums
- classes annotated with @KnownImmutable and known immutables (java.awt.Color, java.net.URI)
- Cloneable classes, collections, maps and arrays, and other classes with special handling
(java.util.Date and various java.time.* classes and interfaces)
Other restrictions apply, please see the groovydoc for ImmutableOptions for further details
```

With the change in this pull request, the script compiles.

![screen shot 2018-10-03 at 3 57 09 pm](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1625920/46444639-afb00300-c727-11e8-8548-3ca0a5a94fee.png)
![screen shot 2018-10-03 at 3 57 40 pm](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1625920/46444640-b0489980-c727-11e8-8ed5-d5510bbc6da9.png)
Merged. Thanks!
As the PR is not binary compatible, so it will be merged into master, i.e. groovy 3

With respect to this commit, there are some issues and other points that deserve discussion on the mailing list:
* we can't just cut and paste the comments from Java source code due to the different licence
* for the methods from Comparable and CharSequence we can use "@inheritDoc" (that will work when doing javadoc and we should use that approach for groovydoc too - even though we need to fix usage of that feature for groovydoc - there is an existing issue)
* for other methods when can either paraphrase in our own wording and/or point to the related String methods using "@see"
* it's a bit confusing for the methods overlapping with those from StringGroovyMethods, e.g. `contains`, was there a reason to replace them - if so we should have that commented somewhere
* for many other methods, Groovy's runtime and static compiler already handle the GString to String conversion, was there a reason to provide implementations since we used to get them for free

Thanks Jacob and Pascal! Merged with Pascal's suggested change and some other minor tweaks.

LGTM.
Would you mind to create a JIRA ticket to track the issue? ( https://issues.apache.org/jira/projects/GROOVY/summary )

This is just a first small step. I don't get the vmplugin warnings with or without indy but perhaps there are scenarios I haven't test yet. Of course, it then moves onto the CachedClass warnings next which this doesn't cover at all and that is where nearly all of the warnings come from. I'll see if @blackdrag has any comments.
Merged (with minor tweaks), thanks!
Awesome, thanks!

I have found one test case that was causing infinite loop after introducing this change. There was a single test that expected this side effect here:

https://github.com/apache/groovy/pull/815/commits/3203663ea639fb4a166500ee4540316f29768a09#diff-b84bc33dfef2f85241cb2fbd31887719

After introducing the change this `while (m)` evaluates to `true` always, while this test expects that it evaluates to `true` one time and jumps out of the while-loop.

I started wondering what is the better choice: keep coercion that mutates the state of the matcher, or replace it with less confusing solution. I guess such breaking change could be introduced in `3.0.0`.

We upgraded to 2.5.3 and the problem persists, so now I had to adjust our cleanup code to use `classRef` instead of `klazz`.

It would be great if the root cause of this would be fixed, i.e. Groovy shouldn't leak strong references to classes. You've replaced the `klazz` reference with a weak one, but the `dgmMetaMethods` field will still transitively hold strong references to any classes used as method return types etc. Therefor their classloaders will also be leaked, creating giant metaspace leaks.

https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARIES-1854 adds a new feature to spi-fly supporting ServiceLoader.load(Class, ClassLoader). With this the actual hack to groovy code seems to be obsolete! I'll give it a try soon.
@paulk-asert : Work's for me now even without changing groovy code.
As no one refuses the PR, I will merge it at this weekend.

I like this idea. Seems worth an email to the dev list. I also wonder whether we need a way to escape curly braces if I want a line that isn't interpolated - one that might actually match an existing property name.

We should support escaping curly braces.
In addition, I plan to support importing multiple properties files and accessing properties in groovy script

We can escape curly braces with `{{...}}`, e.g. `{{abc}}` will be translated as `{abc}`, and `${{abc}}` will be translated as `${abc}`.
In addition, evaluating script is disabled by default, but we can enable it via passing parameter to constructors.
@paulk-asert : Chance to get this patch into 2.5.4?
I have only implemented string concatenation and +,-,/,* for ints and doubles. If folks can test these out I can expand to more types.
Merged! Thanks for reporting the issue and your patience while we got it merged.
Yay!
If you had a multi-threaded Swing app that was displaying tail of a file, wouldn't Thread.yield be relevant? Well at least one 1-core machines?

As the javadoc shows, the read count is 0 when and only when the buffer size is 0.

https://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/io/InputStream.html#read(byte[],%20int,%20int)

Your analysis seems correct. I tried to go back in the commit history and looks like it is lost why that line was added. It's over 10 years old - perhaps very old JDK versions had different behavior. In any case, I think we can ignore it and go with your change.
I changed one existing test since the bytecode now produced looks closer to what Javac produces for that case.

While your suggestion is possibly fine, it would be good to dive into this a bit more to understand what is going on. It would seem strange that type is null at that point. What seems a little weird to me is that your stack trace has:

`java.lang.Throwable.getLocalizedMessage (Throwable.java:391)`

which should be making a call to `Throwable#getMessage()`.
Instead we see in your stacktrace a call to `MissingMethodException#getMessage()`.
It would be good to know that the runtime didn't pick the wrong method at that point.
Otherwise we might be fixing the wrong thing.

Do you have a simple standalone example that can reproduce the error?
It might also be interesting to add @CompileStatic to the method (if possible) and see if the results change.

Time to write some adoc doco for these new collector methods? ;-)

I'll try to have a bit of a better look on the plane flight to Java2days. I guess we should have `avg` for non-streams too. I also wonder whether there are any naming alterations needed to make stream and non-stream versions align? I'll go through some examples and let you know.
I'll try to set aside some to write some doco.
Probably not the final version since it relies on a hack which will require some work for the static type checker.

https://github.com/apache/groovy/commit/334f7d7fd3634652fce3a92486339361538fbb47

I have a point here. Not sure whether I can  post....

- Using the `ExtensionModule` feature, we have implemented multiple methods for easy `String` handling. Ex. `println 'some text here'.md5`
- After this, intuitively I started coding as `println "some $var".md5`. But, it fails with error `No such property: md5 for class: org.codehaus.groovy.runtime.GStringImpl`
- So, any method that is available in the `String` class in groovy environment due to a any of the below reasons, they should be made available in `GString` also. 
     * `String`'s native methods
     * Using groovy extension module facilty
     * custom meta class
     * methods in StringGroovyMethods
- Yes. There will be can be more than one method impls with same signature in these places. Groovy runtime can resolve the calls with some order. With some proper documentation, it can be educated to developers or script writers.

`StringGroovyMethods` has lot of overloadings as `GString` variant to make the users feel transparant between `String` and `GString`. The idea is right. But, the way the methods are given to `GString` is very manual and can be made automatic using some ways...
FYI, `'abc'.md5()`

> FYI, `'abc'.md5()`

```bash
adithyan@adithyan:~$ groovy -e 'println "abc".md5()'
Caught: groovy.lang.MissingMethodException: No signature of method: java.lang.String.md5() is applicable for argument types: () values: []
Possible solutions: any(), is(java.lang.Object), any(groovy.lang.Closure), use([Ljava.lang.Object;), use(java.util.List, groovy.lang.Closure), use(java.lang.Class, groovy.lang.Closure)
groovy.lang.MissingMethodException: No signature of method: java.lang.String.md5() is applicable for argument types: () values: []
Possible solutions: any(), is(java.lang.Object), any(groovy.lang.Closure), use([Ljava.lang.Object;), use(java.util.List, groovy.lang.Closure), use(java.lang.Class, groovy.lang.Closure)
        at script_from_command_line.run(script_from_command_line:1)
```
Also, my point is not only for this one method. It is about the availability of all the methods in `String` in groovy environment in `GString` also.. Thanks
Groovy 2.5.4 is required to use `md5` DGM.

+1. As further background, we have delayed doing such changes earlier since having such differences between branches makes applying patches more difficult - often leads to manual merge fixes which although simple, can be a little painful for large patches. Since 2.5 and 3.0 both now have JDK 7 min (8 for 3.0) I think it is safe to do this change. If we ever want to backport some fixes and re-release another 2.4 release, we'll have to be a little careful. I'd recommend applying to both 2_5_X/master branches (where applicable) using two commits if needed (and if it makes it easier).
+1. My understanding is that header names are case insensitive but we should use the typical convention of using uppercase for both parts.
Understood. Keep it as it is or apply the patch for all branches.

> Understood. Keep it as it is or apply the patch for all branches.

Yep, all active branches. Of course new code within a branch (e.g. Parrot parser files) wouldn't have that restriction and potentially other areas like plugin code for later JDK versions for instance (e.g. Java9 file only gets compiled on JDK9+ regardless of branch minimum JDK).
Thanks for that. Merged!
Thanks Daniel, I applied to make it into 2.5.6.
I merged this to get it into 2.5.6
ping @melix
Can you give more context for this change? Is it a bugfix for something you saw? If so can you write a test?

My personal analysis on this is the following.... as long as count is only changed within a lock/unlock sequence volatile should be good enough. But the rehash methods do not guarantee that. But then again the implementation would be broken if they do not lock on rehash... actually I wonder who is actually calling that method.

My conclusion: Get rid of these classes. Java's concurrent hash map provides much better functionality, much better tested and afaik with a better performance profile.
Merged, thanks!
@melix I run static analysis from time to time, the potential issue was found by the tool. It is related to thread safe, so it's not easy to create a reproducable test...
@blackdrag Thanks for your analysis 😄 and your advice is always helpful.
It would certainly be good to do a quick benchmark check with those classes replaced before deprecating them if performance isn't impacted.

performance check sure... but how? Just any micro benchmark won't do, because that tells us about performance in that micro benchmark only. So it has to be a benchmark based on the actual use. That is not so easy to do.

Well, I wasn't going to test performance in any generic sense - just checking before and after build completion times (and potentially stress/performance subprojects) was all I had in mind. That won't ensure that all users aren't impacted but would give us a quick indication of whether things were about the same or if something was particularly bad.
